supporting_quotes: Brundtland became leader of the Labour Party in 1981 and held the office until resigning in 1992, during her third term as prime minister.
events.notes: Leadership role in Norwegian political party

supporting_quotes: Educated as a physician, Brundtland joined the Labour Party and entered the government in 1974 as Minister of the Environment.

events.canonical_org_name: Brundtland Commission (World Commission on Environment and Development)
supporting_quotes: In 1983, Brundtland was invited by then United Nations Secretary-General Javier Pérez de Cuéllar to establish and chair the World Commission on Environment and Development (WCED), widely referred to as the Brundtland Commission.
After the end of her term as PM, Brundtland was then elected Director-General of the World Health Organization in May 1998.
Director-General of the World Health Organization. 1998–2003.
Brundtland was recognized in 2003 by Scientific American as their 'Policy Leader of the Year' for coordinating a rapid worldwide response to stem outbreaks of SARS.

roles: UN Special Envoy for Climate Change
supporting_quotes: In May 2007, UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon named Brundtland...to serve as UN Special Envoys for Climate Change.
and served as director-general of the World Health Organization and as UN special envoy on Climate Change from 2007 to 2010.
She was appointed Deputy Chair of the group in 2013 and was succeeded in this role by Ban Ki-moon and Graça Machel in 2018.
events.notes: Leadership role in global advocacy group

deduplication_log.reasoning: Same organization (Labour Party), overlapping periods, same role (Leader)
Different roles (Leader vs Minister) at same organization during overlapping periods
Different roles (Director-General vs Special Envoy) at different organizations during overlapping periods
